About twelve or one o'clock he came and knocked at my door; there are two or three people more in the lodging house; with that they told us we might go to bed, we should be very safe; and when we awaked in the morning we found the door wide open. It was a common lodging house.
Q. To Prosecutor. On the solemn oath you have taken, did you give her that waistcoat? - I did not.
Q. Did you give her any money? - Only some money to get some beer.
Q. You staid with her all night? - I did, when I found I had lost my bundle.
GUILTY . (Aged 54.)

Imprisoned one year in the House of Correction and
fined 1s.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

458.
FRANCES HUGHES
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 5th of September , a cotton handkerchief, value 6d. and eight shillings and sixpence in monies numbered ; the goods and monies of
Jeremiah Mackay
.
JERMIAH MACKAY sworn.

I am a watchman ; I went along with this woman, and she and I were in bed together; I fell asleep, and she got up and went away, and left the door open, and I did not miss her till the girl of the house came up and awaked me.
Q. Did you know this woman before? - Yes.

Q. Did you live with her? - No, I did not; she lodged in a place called Church-lane, St. Giles's
.
Q. What time of the night did you go to her? - About six o'clock.
Q. Before you went on your duty? - Yes.

Q. What time did she go away? - I cannot say. The girl came up to me at nine o'clock, and asked me where she was? I said, I did not know; the girl asked me if I had any money? I told her I had. I missed eight shillings and sixpence, and my pocket handkerchief; I was sober enough.
Q. You knew where to find this woman the next day? - No, I did not.
Q. You knew where she lodged? - She told me the present time she lodged there; but I did not know where she lodged the next night.
Q. Did you enquire? - No, I did not.
Q. What was you to give her? - She asked nothing at all. I did not tell her about any thing, only went to bed along with her.

Q. You made some bargain? - Only to go along with her. I had been with her once before in the same house. I told the watchman belonging to the place if he see her to take her up; and so he did. I cannot swear whether it was she or the girl that awaked me took it.
Not GUILTY .
Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

459.
JOHN SCHROEDER
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 25th of August , a cotton gown, value 2s. the goods of
John Smout
.

MARGARET SMOUT
sworn.

I am the wife of
John Smout
, housekeepers, at No. 15, Old street, Soho
; the prisoner at the bar came and knocked at the door, and the maid opened the door, and he presented this bill; I was not present; she rung the bell; Mr. Cokum came down stairs; I came down while he was in the passage; I was coming up the street when he knocked at the door; I did not hear him knock.

Q. Where did you find the prisoner standing? - Within the passage. I went up and stood at the yard door, with my child in my arms, the yard of the house, and Mr. Cokum came down stairs, and he gave Mr. Cokum this paper; I see him, and Mr. Cokum turned it over, seeing so many names, but he could not make any thing out of it.

Q. Did he give it you? - No, he did not. We found it in the passage, before we took him out of the passage, Mr. Cokum could not understand what he said, he spoke German, he would not speak English; and Mr. Cokum says, come up stairs, I have one of your countrymen in my shop, and he will tell me what you want. With that he went up stairs, and I stood at the yard door, and I heard the shop door shut, and I heardthe foot coming down stairs, and I heard it stop.

Q. Which is the shop door? - It is the top of the house. I heard the foot stop, and I turned from the yard door to go up stairs, and I met him on the last flight of stairs; he had got something under his coat; I said, what have you got there? and he said nothing, but pushed by me, and I stopped him at the parlour and pulled the gown from under his coat.
Q. Where was this gown kept? - It was laying on the cradle; I had it to cover my child in the cradle, in the dining room, in the first floor.
Q. Did he pass that dining room to come out of the shop? - Yes. I have kept it ever since.
Q. You are sure it is your's? - Yes.
Q. When did you find that paper? -After he was taken away, to go to the justice. He got away, and they called out after him and brought him back.

Prisoner. I went there to enquire for Mr. Smout, who is a Sweedish gentleman. Ask her whether the gown was not on the same premises when I was brought back again? - Yes, because at our parlour door I pulled the property from under his coat, and then he got out of the street door.
Prisoner. When I came down stairs the gown was on the banisters; she said so before the justice? - No, it was in the cradle.
Court. You did not see him come out of the dining room? - I did not.

JAMES KENNEDY
sworn.

I am an officer belonging to Marlborough-street. On the 25th of August, there was a call of stop thief; in the street; the prosecutor lives just by my house; I went to the street and took the prisoner into custody; the mob was about him at the time.
Prisoner. That gentleman did not take me, a shoe-maker took me.
Court to Kennedy. He was delivered up to you, I suppose? - Yes.

Q. How far was this from the house of the lady? - A hundred yards, not much further. I took him strait to the office, and I told her to follow me to Marlborough-street office; she was among the people.
Q. What did she charge him with? - With taking a gown.
Q. Did the shew you a gown at that time? - No. In searching him I found these fourteen petticoats, and every one of them is to a different trade, signed all by a surgeon.

Prisoner. When I came to this gentlewoman's house, I was recommended by a German, with a letter; I went up stairs, coming down stairs they gave me an answer that I was to call again the next day. There was a gown on the banisters, and when I came down stairs I never touched the gown at all; I am as innocent as a child unborn; I came out and went out of doors, and the lady called out stop him! and a shoe-maker stopped me; the said Mr. Kennedy did not make his appearance at all, he was only the officer in Marlborough-street. When we did come there I was committed to New Prison, Clerkenwell; I was there from Tuesday till Saturday, and then I was discharged from the justice; the lady did not make her appearance, and then I was remanded back to New Prison for three weeks; then on Saturday they found a bill against me, which I am as innocent of as a child unborn. I was quite entirely discharged from the justice.

Court to Prosecutrix. Was this man examined once or twice? - He was only examined once before me; he was to be brought up the next day on account of a watch that he had on him; theythought to find out to whom it belonged.
Prisoner. Mr. Kirby knows very well. I have a wife and three small children, and have lost one of my eyes.
Court to Prosecturix. Was he brought back to the house? - Yes, the mob brought him back, and then as we were going from the house again Mr. Kennedy met him.
GUILTY . (Aged 26)
Transported for seven years .
Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

460.
ELIZABETH TRIMBETH
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 22d of August , a silk purse, value 3d. six guineas, and eighteen shillings ; the goods and monies of
Amantero Sieys
.
AN INTERPRETER sworn.

AMANTERO SIEYS
sworn.

I am from a place called Masita, near Marseilles; I am a sailor . After my supper, on the 22d of August, at half past nine, I went to a public-house, the corner of Well-street, Ratcliff-highway
; there were three of us together; we were drinking a pot of beer; the other two went out and left me in the public house; I drew out my purse and took out a sixpence, to pay for the pot of beer which I had; the landlord returned me the change, and at the same time I went out; and this young woman was in the room when I paid the landlord; when I went out the girl followed me, she followed me into the middle of the street, passed the side of me and drew the purse from my pocket; she instantly ran across the road, and I could not find her; she ran into some house; it was only two or three steps to run across. I remained in the middle of the road frightened, the shortest thing that I thought was to go and advise with the landlord where I was drinking. Then I went about to all the houses, and there enquired after her, and could not find her. The publican asked me where I lived? I told him at Mr. Bush's; we went to Mr. Bush's, and the publican, and Mr. Bush and me went in pursuit of this girl; after they were in the road they desired me to go back and leave them together; that if in case the girl should perceive me, she might have some suspicion; and I returned to the public house; Mr. Bush and the publican went in search of this girl in different places till they found her.
Q. Did you ever find your money? - It is impossible to find it.
Q. Are you sure that is the young woman? - Yes. I felt her hand in my pocket. It contained six guineas in gold, and eighteen shillings in silver.
JOSEPH BARE sworn.

I keep the Marquis of Cornwallis public house, the corner of Well-street. On Saturday night, between nine and ten, this man came into my house and called for a pot of beer; about ten o'clock he went away; this girl was going out with him; he paid me for a pot of beer out of his purse, and the girl stood close by with him; I see them go out together. A short time after the poor man came in all of a frustration; he could not speak any English, and I could not rightly understand what was the matter with him, till he shewed me that somebody had taken something out of his pocket; I could just make out a few words, that he lodged at Mr. Bush's; I went with him to Mr. Bush's, and I asked Mr. Bush to explain what it was that man meant.

Q. What is the prisoner? - I believe she is a girl of the town; she had come in for a pot of ale, but by some means or other she got into acquaintance with this man; they went out in company together posit vely. Then Mr. Bush told me how he was robbed; I went immediately in pursuit along with Mr. Bush, and between eleven and twelve I apprehended the prisoner, the same night; I see her have all these new things in her possession, and a quantity of clothes, which I thought fit to take from her. I found a number of gold rings, which she said she had been purchasing that night. There were eighteen shillings found on her, and six shillings and sixpence that she said she had given to some girl that was along with her. Here is a new pair of shoes, stockings, garters, gown, cap, new shift, and petticoat.

Q. Did she tell you where she bought all these things? - She was so much in liquor that I could hardly make out what she said. The folks of the house said that she had lost half a guinea out of her hand just before, but which I could not find.
Q. Was she in liquor when she left your house? - No.

Q. How do you know she purchased these things that night? - She had no rings on her fingers when she went out of my house, because she paid me for a pot of ale that night. Here are the gold bobs, the ears had been bored that night.

Prisoner. Mr. Bare sent a woman to pull the ear rings out of my ears, and she made my ears bleed. Mr. Bush will be upon his oath that that man had but eighteen pence when he came out. I went in first into Mr. Bare's house, I went in for a pot of ale, for a boatswain of a ship that was at our house; with that this old gentleman was there; he had been there drinking all day, and he spoke to me, and I went out with him, and there were two girls at the door, and he stopped talking to them, About two hours after I was drinking in a public house, and Mr. Bare came and took me over to his house, and searched me all over, and took a locket off my neck, and put me in the watch-house, and on Monday he came and put me in Newgate, and this gentleman came and said that if I would make up the money that I had from him, he would free me of it; I said I had nothing of his; and he gave me some little trisle that he had in his pocket, and bid me good by.

JOHN BABTIST BUSH
sworn.

This man lodged with me a fortnight, and the very next day after he paid me a guinea and a half, and I gave him eighteen-pence in change, and he said that was all he had in the world, and the next day he came and borrowed some money to buy some tobacco, and I lent it him, and afterwards he came to me about ten o'clock, and told me that he had been robbed of some money; Mr. Bare asked me to be so kind as to go with him, and he would go and seek for the girl; I went with Mr. Bare round Rosemary lane, and he found the girl at a public house, and we took her, I did not know the girl, the prosecutor says, that is the girl.
Q. When did he tell you he had no money? - On the 13th of August, he paid me the guinea and a half, and told me that he had no more money than that, and I gave him eighteen pence change.

Court to Bare. When he pulled out his purse what money had he in it? - I did not see what he had in it, but since the 13th I have changed one or two guineas at my house; I think there was some money in the purse.
Q. To Sieys. How came you to tell Mr. Bush that you had no more money? - I did not say so
Q. What did you pay on the 14th of August? - A guinea and a half.
Q. How much money had you on the 14th of August? - Nine guineas and a half.

ELIZABETH CONNER
sworn.

I am a grocer and cheesemonger; the prisoner's parents are honest just people; I have known her for four years, she has been in and out of my house, and I have not known her guilty of the least injustice in my life; her parents to my knowledge maintains her.
Q. She is not on the town at all? - Not to my knowledge, her father lives in Stepney Causeway, the number of the house I cannot tell, but it is a remarkable white house, let out in tenements.
Q. How far is that from Well-street? - I cannot pretend to say.
Bare. About a mile.
Conner. She is a very sober young woman, I know I never see her disguised upon my oath.
Q. What age is she? - I cannot pretend to say; her father is a labouring man, he has foremerly been a seafaring man, and he works in some ship now, and is an honest just man.

ANN NICHOLS
sworn.

I am a sailor's wife, I live in East Smithfield; I have known the prisoner not quite three months, she is a poor misfortunate girl, and did what she could for her living; this young woman has been very honest since I knew her, she lives in Vinegar-yard, just by Well-street.
Q. You never heard whether she had in the last three months lived at Stepney Causeway? - Her father and mother lived there.
Q. She then lived with her father and mother? - No, she did not.
Q. To Prosecutor. When you came out of the public house, did you speak to any other woman at all? - I spoke to me one at all, there was nobody there but this one person.
Q. To Bare. Did you happen to see whether there were any other women at the door? - I did not see any other, I was not out of doors directly.
GUILTY . (Aged 17.)

Imprisoned three months in Newgate and and
fined 1s.
Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

461.
THOMAS LEGGE
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 4th of September , fourteen pounds weight of lead, value 18d. belonging to
Richard Jefferies
, affixed to a certain dwelling of his .

RICHARD JEFFERIES
sworn.
I am a carpenter . On Friday, the 4th of this month, the lead was lost from a house that I was going to raise the story.

Q. You have the lease of it? - Yes. About five o'clock I met the prisoner with the lead, coming out of the premises, wrapped up in a flannel jacket, under his arm, I see him coming out, I waited till he came up to me, and asked him what he had got under his arm? he made answer, nothing belonging to you sir? On that I insisted on his turning his waistcoat aside, and I see it was lead, with that I said, you rascal, you have been robbing me of lead; with that I attempted to get it from under his arm, he tried to prevent it, but I got it from him, and I found it was the hopper head of a trunk; I got a carpenter's chissel to open it, is that which first of all receives the water from the gutter of the roof, to carry it to the pipe, it is like a square bason; I see it inthe morning, I suppose about six o'clock.
Q. Was it fixed there safe? - Yes, it was fixed to the wall by a couple of wall hooks.

Q. Did it appear to you that the lead was recently taken? - Yes, by the wall hooks, which were drawn out, they were thrown away, there was nothing to cut, he took it compleatly, because it is nothing to cut.
Q. Did you examine the place from whence it was taken? - I did, the same day, and the two holes corresponded exactly with the two holes where the hold fasts were.

Q. Have you any doubt it is your's? - None, perfectly satisfied. When I took the prisoner, instead of acknowledging his fault, he upt with his fist and knocked me down, and I believe he would have murdered me had it been in his power; he did not compleatly knock me down, but he knocked me as far as your lordship, and then I went after him and tripped up his heels, and he got up again, and I knocked him down three times.

Q. Did he strike you with his fist first? - Yes, he did, after I had got the lead from him he struck me a blow just on the side of my temple. He was a task master bricklayer , and I had employed him at that time to do some work by the rod.
Mr. Jackson. Was this person in your employ? - I had engaged him to do some brick work for me; he had not done any thing.
Q. In whose employ may you be? - In my own.
Q. What other descriptions of trades might be employed in repairing of this house? - Carpenters.
Q. No plumbers? - No.
Q. How many carpenters might be employed in the house? - Two.
Q. How many bricklayers? - Not one.
Q. I think you said that you was raising the roofs of these house? - Yes.
Q. How long might they have been your houses? - About two years.

Q. Will you have the goodness to describe the contract between Mr. Wright and you, respecting these houses? - I made an agreement to sell him the two houses when the attick story was carried up; there was a specific sum agreed upon when this atrick story was carried up.
Q. Who was to pay the bricklayer? - Me.
Q. Had you happened to receive any earnest money of Mr. Wright? - Not a shilling.
Q. Was your agreement in writing? - Not a word of it.
Q. You have been always good friends with this man up to this time? - Yes.
Q. Does there happen to be any account existing between him and you? - He had done a garden wall for me.
Q. When this happened were you in his debt? - No.

Q. Had he been impertinent enough to tell you that you owed him five pounds? - I never paid him five pounds in my life, the work that he did for me had not amounted but to thirty shillings in the whole, and I gave him a guinea and a half, and he left the work.
Q. Did he ever ask you for any further sum that you owed him? - No.
Q. I think you have described a pretty good pitched battle at this taking, you did not strike the first blow? - No.
Q. You did not d-n his eyes for a rascal and a thief? - I told him he was a scoundrel and a thief.
Q. What progress had you made in taking off the roof? - The rafters were taken down, and the top most likely uncovered.
Q. The lead had been all taken off of course? - That was taken away by theplumbers two or three days before.

Q. In the course of clearing the lead from different houses, have you ever employed the prisoner for that purpose? - Yes, one particular time I did, but that was another house, about a twelve month ago, and I forgot the lead, and I asked him to bring it down from the garret.

Q. I think by your own account you knocked him down three times; did you happen to continue in possession of his person; pray did you let him go home? - He went away after I took the lead from him; I went to get the patrols to take him up; I did detain him a considerable time, but afterwards I left him in the care of two carpenters while I went for the patrol, and he got away from them, and I found him at home, laying on the bed, and his wife denied him.
Q. You did not say that you would make him repent of this? - I did not.
Q. Nor nothing of that kind? - No.
Q. Did he happen to say to you, I will go with you where you please? - No, not a single syllable of that sort.
Q. Did he not say after you had struck him, you are a bad man, did not I tell you where I found it, and I was coming with it to you? - No.
Q. Has it ever happened to you to be in any embarrassment about lead? - No.
Q. Never called upon by any legal process whatever, to answer for a mistake of your own in having taken lead? - Never.
Q. Do you happen to know that the prisoner at the bar was ever subpoenaed against you, to give evidence against you? - Yes.

Q. Then in point of fact something like a legal process has issued against you for mistaking property in lead? - No, it was my own property. When I built this house, the house came to fifteen hundred pounds, it was built according to contract; there was a man that I employed in the building gave wrong dimensions to the plumber; when the lead was brought there, and laid down in this roof, one Mr. Dixon said, this is not the exact lead that is in my agreement; I was under the necessity of taking that lead up and get fresh lead, but there was some that I put into the gutters and other parts, and there was a certain quantity left behind, and there was an action about the extras for two hundred and fifty pounds; Mr. Dixon said there was lead left in the house, and that I had not allowed for this lead that I had taken away from his house; it was an action that I brought against him.
Q. In that case, whatever the description of it was, he was subpoenaed against you? - He was, but he never came forward.
Q. Since then there has been some little interruption in your friendship? - Never, or else I would not have done all I could to recommend him.

Q. You have stated that other persons were employed in the house besides this man, might they not have taken the lead from the part to which it was supposed to be detached, as well as himself? - They might have done so.
Q. Had the lead of the gutters been taken down? - Certainly, and locked up, this had no connection whatever with him.
Q. And this hopper remained with two nails? - It has no other support, it has no support from the gutter.
Q. Pray did Mr. Wright come in and out pretty often? - He did, sometimes.
Q. Who happens to have the key? - There was no key on the door, the workmen were at work at five o'clock.

Q. In the course of the visits of Mr. Wright, he gave directions how he would have things go on? - He was to receive no orders but from me; I don't think at this time that Mr. Wright had been there at all. I pointed out the way in whichI meant to do it, and he was satisfied.

Prisoner. On the 1st of September I erected a scaffold at the front of these two houses; in the evening Mr. Wright's carpenter took the lead down from these buildings; on the 4th of September I went to the building to see for Mr. Jefferies, for some materials to mix up the lime, to get on with the brick work, and I did not see Mr. Jefferies there; I went down into the lower part of the house, and I found this property among the rubbish, and the carpenters were at work on the premises at the same time; it was either ten minutes before five, or after, I am not certain which.
Court to Prosecutor. What time did you go to your house that night? - About five o'clock.
Q. What time did you go to the prisoner's house? - It might be in the course of two hours.
Mr. Jackson. It was not ten o'clock? - No, I fancy he was in St. Martin's round-house by that time.
The prisoner called seven witnesses who gave him a good character.
GUILTY . (Aged 24.)
Transported for seven years .
Tried by the second Middlesex Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

462.
MARY MOORE
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 10th of September , nine yards of printed cotton, value 12s the goods of
Robert MacGlew
, privately on his shop .

ROBERT MAC GLEW
sworn.

I live in Bishopsgate-street
, a linen draper ; the prisoner at the bar came into my shop on Thursday, the 10th of September, a little after eight in the evening, and desired to look at some printed callico for a gown, I shewed her several, she did not fix on any of them, she desired me to shew her some at all wide; I shewed her several of them, she did not fix on any of them; I then went round to the cottons, and I observed when I came back again the prisoner's gown in a very awkward manner, as if something were under it; I shewed her several more, but she did not fix on any of them, she liked one pretty well, she said she would determine of it that night, and come the next morning for it; I was taking the prints that I had shewn, to see if there were any which she might like, which she had seen; when I was doing that she turned on her heel and wished me a good night, and went out; I then jumped over the counter, and desired the shopman to run after her, and stop her immediately, which he did, he overtook her about a dozen yards from the door; I followed him likewise myself, and began to feel about for the gown, where I thought the bundle was, then it was gone; the shopman that laid hold of her first, here it lays, I I see him pick it up, I brought her in and had her examined.
Prisoner. Was there not another man in the shop, looking at goods the same time? - There was, the man was a neighbour.
Q. What is your man's name? - Atkinson, he is not here, the boy is, I could not possibly bring them both; Atkinson was at the opposite counter.

JAMES DAY
sworn.

Q. How old are you? - Seventeen. I am servant to Robert Mac Glew. On Thursday night between eight and nine o'clock the 10th of September last; Mary Moore came into the shop and asked to look at some printed callicoes for a gown; some time after she went out; I see mymaster shew her a great many goods, and when she went out he told the shopman to stop her, and I immediately went to the door, and we were about a dozen yards from the door, and I see her drop this piece of printed callico, and I see the young man stop her, and he picked it up. There were no other customers in the shop.
Q. Where was Atkinson? - Behind the opposite counter.
- SAPWELL sworn.
I produce the cotton, I received it of the prosecutor.
Prosecutor. I am sure it is mine, there are several marks, it has been in the house these six years almost
Prisoner. I am quite innocent, I have nothing more to say, I hope you will consider that my friends are all in the country, and I have got nobody here to speak for me.
GUILTY,
Of stealing, but not privately in the shop . (Aged 21.)

Imprisoned three months in Newgate and
fined 1s.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

462.
JOHN SCOTT
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 22d of August , two pounds weight of raw coffee, value 3s. the goods of
Aaron Brandon
and
Samuel Cortissos
.
A Second COUNT, laying them to be the property of persons unknown.

JOHN BOHAM
sworn.
I am a locker in the service of the Customs.

Q. Were you stationed on the 22d of August at the warehouses of Messrs. Brandon and Cortissos? - Yes, at St. Helens
.
Q. Do you know the prisoner at the bar? - Yes.
Q. Was he employed in these warehouses? - Yes, as a cooper , I have always understood.
Q. Did you see him on the 22d of August, and under what circumstances? -About one o'clock he came down stairs from some of the floors of the warehouses up stairs.
Q. Do you know whether there were any coffee lodged in these warehouses? - Yes, a large quantity in casks and bags, all raw coffee.

Q. Are the casks secured? - Some were secured and some not; they all undergo a process, and as the business will admit they are opened and kept so. He came down to the outer door warehouse, and called me by my name, and said he was going, I came to him immediately to examine him, as is our usual way, I examined his pockets and about his waist, I found nothing, I felt on his arms something like raw coffee on each arm, the small part above the elbow, I felt his breast, and I felt there likewise coffee, as I supposed it to be; on that I told him I could not let him pass, he attempted to run up stairs, I followed him, and brought him into the counting house, he pulled off his coat, a string was tied round each arm above the elbow, which I untied, and a quantity of raw coffee fell out, he then pulled his shirt out of his breeches, and there likewise fell a quantity of raw coffee from his breast; Mr. Leave was present, an excise locker, and Mr. Cortissos.
Q. Did the prisoner say any thing how he came by the coffee? - No, he did not.
Q. What quantity of coffee was there? - About two pounds and a half.
Q. The same kind of coffee as in your warehouses? - Yes.
Q. West India coffee? - Yes.

STEPHEN LEATE
sworn.
Q. I believe you are an excise locker; were you present at the warehouses the day this matter happened? - I was, I was present when he was searched, Mr. Boham called me to his assistance.
Q. What was found? - Raw coffee in the sleeves of his coat, he pulled off his coat, and the strings were loosened, and the coffee fell on the table, and there was coffee in the bosom of his shirt.
Q. Did he give any account how he came by it? - He did not.

SAMUEL CORTISSOS
sworn.
Q. You have warehouses? - Yes.
Q. Had you coffee in your warehouses? - A great quantity, belonging to different merchants, in casks, barrels, and bags.

Prisoner. I have got a great impediment in my speech; this coffee that I am charged with, is a little raw dirty coffee, we cannot help spilling the coffee in coopering the casks, and if I had put it into the casks I might have spoiled the sale of it; I thought I might make free to take it to my family to clean, for I have got a very large family, four children.
Q. To Bobum. Was it clean coffee at the time you found it? - Yes, it is clean now.
Q. What is it worth? - About three shillings before the duty is paid.
GUILTY . (Aged 56.)

Imprisoned three months in Newgate and
fined 1s.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

464.
JAMES WATSON
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting on the King's highway,
Benjamin Brown
, on the 28th of May , putting him in fear and feloniously taking from his person and against his will, four bank notes, value 5l. each; five other bank notes, value 10l. each; two other bank notes, value 15l. each; one other bank notes, value 30l. and another, value 20l. the property of
William Ogilby
.

BENJAMIN BROWN
sworn.

I am a butler to
William Ogilby
, Esq . No. 43, Harley-street. On the 28th of May I was sent to Mr. Boldero's, in Cornhill, for a hundred and fifty pounds, which I got in thirteen bank notes, four fives, five tens, two fifteens, a thirty, and a twenty. I put them in my waistcoat pocket, and at the corner of Milk-street, Cheapside
, I was met by several people, three in particular hustled me; the first came up with his eloow to my left shoulder, another came right before me, and a third came right under my right arm, which I believe to be the prisoner at the bar, and which I believe took the notes out of my pocket; then a fourth came up and pretends to ask me what I had lost? and pointed down Milk-street, and said, the man was gone down there: they made off, and I could see no more of them.

Q. Did they go down Milk-street? - I don't think they did. He that came to ask me what I had lost, so much took my attention that I could hardly take notice; I told him I had lost a hundred and fifty pounds.
Q. What reason have you to charge this man with it? Are you sure he is one? - Yes, I do recollect him before.
Q. How soon afterwards was he taken? - I don't know exactly; I believe it was the 13th or 14th of July.
Q. What time of the day was this? - About one o'clock in the day. He was taken by picking another gentleman's pocket. I had information at Bow-street,and they knew the person by my information.
Q. When was it you see him? - The 14th of July, at Bow street.
Q. Are You able to swear that this was the man that came under your right arm? - Yes.
Q. Have you any doubt on the subject? - Not the least doubt.

Q. What was it that made the first stoppage? - That I do not recollect; there came a good crowd; I pulled my coat down, and I had no sooner done that than a taller man than the prisoner struck me with his elbow, and one rather shorter than him came before, and this is the shortest that got under my right arm, I have not the least doubt.
Q. If you had not seen him at Bow-street, should you have known him again? - I should.
Mr. Knapp. Were you at any other office besides Bow street? Were you at Hatton-garden? - I was.
Q. Was the prisoner at the bar there? - No. I was sent for there to see another, but it was a boy.
Q. Have you always been as certain to the person of the prisoner? - Yes, as being one of the three.
Q. Did you say so at Bow-street? - I did, that he was one of the three.
Q. Had you any doubt more than you have now? - None in the least.
Q. There was a great crowd in Cheapside, occasioned by the Lord Mayor going in procession to St. Paul's? - I believe it was.
Q. You say one of the persons came directly before you; the prisoner under your right arm; why he must be stooping at the time? - I don't think he stopped much.
Q. Do you think he did not stop at all? - I don't think he did.
Q. Had you as good an opportunity of seeing the prisoner, that was stooping under your arm, as the man that was facing of you? - I turned to him instantly.
Q. You put these notes that you have described, into your waistcoat pocket loose? - All wrapped up together.
Q. You put them into your pocket in Cornhill? - No, in Mr. Boldero's office.
Q. Had you seen them again before you got to Milk-street? - No.
Q. Did you feel them before you got to Milk-street? - Yes, several times.
Q. When you felt yourself in a crowd, you buttoned your coat together; that was not till you got to Milk-street? - My coat was not buttoned, because it is rather too little.
Q. Do you mean to swear that those notes were in your pocket when you got to Milk-street? - Yes, I am positive of it, not only that, but I had my hand on them not six yards before.

Q. Originally I took you to say this, that you see the prisoner at the bar, that he was under your right arm, and you believed him to be the man that picked your pocket; and then, when my lord put it to you, the young man's life being at stake, you say you are sure he was the man? - I was sure he was one of the three; I believe him to be the man that picked my pocket, but I did not feel his hand in my pocket; and therefore I did not so positively swear to that.
Q. Have you ever found any of your notes since? - Three of them came to the bank. I know him by his size and way of walking.
Q. His size is not very particular, nor his person neither. Perhaps you have heard of a reward for a highway robbery? - I did not know pick pocketing was a highway robbery.
Q. Don't you know that there is a reward of forty pounds if you convict this man on this charge? - I do not; I can safely swear that.
Q. Were you ever in a court of justice before? - Yes.
Q. You was at Bow - street, had you ever been at Bow-street before? - Yes.
Court. The man that struck you, was that done for the purpose or an accident? - The man came full drive against me with his elbow; it alarmed me a little; I suspected what was the matter.
Q. You are positive as to the man? - Yes.
Prisoner. My lord and gentlemen of the jury, I am innocent of this charge; for about three weeks before I had an accident, and I was very bad, and never was in the street all that day.

ELIZABETH READ
sworn.
I live at the Red Lion, Cloth-fair; my husband keeps the Red Lion.

Q. What is his christian name? - James. I know the prisoner by using our house four or five months; and I recollect, on the night before that this procession, went to St Paul's, his coming very ill to our house, with a pain in his side.

Q. When was the procession to St. Paul's? - The 28th of May, the Thursday in Witsun week. He came in the evening before about nine o'clock, and begged the favour of us to sleep there; and he had bought a bottle of some stuff to take; and I slept out of my bed to let him sleep with my husband; we had but one bed; and he was so ill, he had fell down a brewhouse cellar some time before and had hurt his side; I did not understand whether it was inward or outward. In the morning after, I wished to go and see the procession to St. Paul's; but my husband refused, and went himself, and the prisoner never went out of my house all the day; I made him broth in the course of the day. I staid at home with him the whole day, and he did not go out till five or six o'clock in the evening.
Court. Are you sure it was of a Thursday? - Yes, I am positive it was of a Thursday.
Q. What procession was there on Thursday? - The children going to St. Paul's, as I understood.
Did he come to your house on Wednesday? - Yes, on Wednesday night. My husband is not here.

Q. You was not intimate with this young man? - No more than using my house. I understood him to be a seafaring man , a man just come from sea; I don't know any further than that. The man only came backwards and forwards as another person did.
Q. You had no particular acquaintance with him at all? - No.
Q. Is your husband a young man? - Yes.
Q. So that not being acquainted with him at all, you gave up your bed? - I gave that up on not there account than his being ill. He came in about nine.
Q. This was in May, broad day light? - Yes, it was.
Q. He was able to walk? - He was, he walked to our house.
Q. How far had he walked that day? - I don't know.
Q. Was there no lodgings in Clothfair to be got for him? - He did not try for a lodging.
Q. So you set up all night? - No, I slept with the servants that night.
Q. What servants have you in the house? - Two, both young women,
Q. Did not they think it odd for you to go and leave your husband's bed and sleep with the two maids? - I don't know.
Q. Your husband is not here? - No, he knows nothing of the business.
Q. O, yes, he must! He must know he said with a man instead of laying with you; How came you to six on the day of the procession? - On account of my husband going out to see the procession.
Q. You had no curiosity to ask him then? - I knew it to be the time of the childrens going, and therefore I did not think of asking any further.
Q. Did he tell you whether he got into St. Paul's? - He did not.
Q. Are these two servants with you now? - No, they are not. I don't know exactly when they left me.
Q. What were there names? - I don't know their sirnames; I know their christian names, one of them is Elizabeth.
Q. How long had she lived with you? - Not above a fortnight or three weeks.
Q. Who did she live with before she lived with you? - I don't know where my husband went to enquire her character.
Q. Not you don't know where she lived? - I did not.
Q. Not never asked her name? - Nothing more than Elizabeth.
Q. Did not you ask what kind of people she lived with? - It is so long back I don't know.
Q. What was the other maid servant's name? - Mary.
Q. How long did she live with you? - She might live with me longer or shorter; she was with me a very short time; it might be a month, or it might be less.
Q. Where did she come from? - That I don't know. My husband went to the office at Snow-hill for her. I do not recollect her sirname at present.

Q. What are the names of the two that you have now? - I know the names of them I have now; one of them I have had about six weeks, her name is
Elizabeth Harris
, and I believe the name of the other is
Mary Bell
.

Q. It is very odd that the maids should be exactly the same name. Were they not the servants that lived with you in the month of May? - Upon my outh they were not, I had no character with one of them, for she had lived with my husband's father.
Q. When these other two servants went, where did they go to? - I don't know.
Q. So this sick man was to be with your husband? - Yes, he did on that night. It was my husband's wish, seeing the young man look so bad.
Q. How long did he stay in the house? - Till six o'clock the next evening, and then he went out of the house.
GUILTY.
Of Stealing, but not violently from the person.

Judgment respited
.
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

465.
WILLIAM HILL
was indicted for
feloniously > stealing, on the 7th of July , a linen handkerchief, value 1s. the goods of a certain person unknown .

WILLIAM GHRIMES
sworn.

I am a persumer; I see the prisoner take a handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, on the 7th of July, in Cornhill
, as he was going along; it was a red; handkerchief with white spots, and I sent a man down Cornhill to speak to Mr. Rule, to send him out of the ward, and Rule apprehended him with the gentleman's handkerchief on him.
Q. Did you lose sight of him before he was taken? - I did not.
Q. Did you see the handkerchief in his hand when he was taken? - I did.
Q. Did you tell the gentleman of it? - I did not mean to bring him to justice then, but to send for Mr. Rule to send him out of Cornhill. The gentleman never knew nothing of it.
Prisoner. I am sure he has very much perjured himself.

ANDREW RULE
sworn.
I am warden and constable of Cornhill ward, and street keeper.

Q. Did you see the prisoner pick a gentleman's pocket? - I did not. Mr. Ghrimes gave me an account of it, and I went and see the prisoner at the corner of Exchange-alley, leaning against the corner of the alley, with this very handkerchief that Mr. Ghrimes has sworn to, wrapped round his wrist.
Q. Is it a red handkerchief with white spots? - Yes, it is.

Q. Have you kept it ever since? - I have. I said I had got a charge against him; I desired him to come along with me. He made no resistance, but he came along with me to the compter; and I found two more handkerchiefs on him, two knives, and a pair of sciffars, and six and thirty shillings worth of stamps, which belonged to one Mr. Hart, the corner of Lombard-street; but he would not prosecute.

Prisoner. When you came up to me, Mr. Rule, you asked me what I was about? I told you I was about nothing, I was very much surprised at your asking me that question; says you, you have been picking a gentleman's pocket of this handkerchief! I says, I am surprised at you, I have had it above three months in my own pocket; says you that is nothing to me, I have got a charge of you, and you must go along with me to the compter; and I immediately acquiesced and went with him.
Ghrimes. I am positive to the handkerchief that I see him take from the gentleman.

Prisoner. I should be glad to know whether this young gentleman ever had seen that handkerchief, or had it in his hand before now? - I did before the Lord Mayor, and as soon as it was taken away by the street keeper; I had it in my hand and I am positive it is the same.

Prisoner. I have a person, if it can he admitted, that can swear to that handkerchief, that I had it for upwards of three months in my own possession, and once in washing it she had it a fortnight in her possission.

MARY KELLY
sworn.
I am a poor person; I work at the army work.
Q. Do you know the prisoner? - Yes, I know the handkerchief; it is a small spotted one, rather pale and worn, rather in holes, I think there are two or three.
Q. Have you washed it? - Yes.
Q. What was the colour of it? - Red and white, rather lightish red; I believe I have washed it half a dozen times; I wash his linen.
Q. When did you last wash it? - I take it to be six months ago; I have not washed it for him since.
Court to Rule. Are there any holes in it? - Several. I did not take it from him till I took him to the compter; I did not know that I had any right to search him till I see him to the compter.
Q. Did that woman come to him in the compter, or see the handkerchief that day? - No; I did not know that he had such a woman belonging to him.
Q. To Gbrimes. How far was he from; you when you see him take it? - About two yards. I see it continually in his hand; he never put it in his pocket.
Not GUILTY .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

466.
THOMAS PURSER
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 5th of September , a pair of boys leather shoes, value 4s. the goods of
Richard Day
.

RICHARD DAY
sworn.

I keep a shoe warehouse on Holborn-hill, opposite Hatton-garden
. On Saturday the 5th of September, I was at my tea in the back parlour (it is all in a strait line) this boy came in, and he wanted a pair of shoes; my son came backwards to me and said, here is the muffin boy ;(some time back the prisoner sold muffin) my son was very loath to shew him any, having a suspicion; but he shewed him some, and he tried some on; I told my wife to go into the shop to watch him; in a few minutes my son came back to me, and said, come into the shop, he has stole a pair of shoes. I went forward to the prisoner, and I charged him with it; the prisoner was then in the shop; they were under his coat; he had a great coat on and another coat on; I said, you have stole a pair; says he, stole a pair! yes, says I, there they are under your coat. I took them from under his coat; he begged very hard I would let him go; but I sent for an officer, and gave charge of him. I have kept the shoes till now.
Q. How do you know them to be your shoes? - By my own hand writing, and inside marked D.

RICHARD DAY
sworn.
I am apprentice to my father.

Q. Were you in the shop when the lad came in? - Yes. On Saturday the 5th of September, the prisoner came into the shop and wanted a pair of shoes; I shewed them to him; while I turned my back to get some more, the prisoner took a pair and put them under his coat; my mother see him. I see my father take them from under the boy's coat. There is his own hand writing on them.
Q. Do you know your father's hand writing? - Yes. These are our shoes.

Prisoner. I went into this gentleman's shop, on Saturday afternoon, and asked for a pair of shoes; there was nobody in the shop; I stamoed with my foot, and that young man came, and he asked me what I wanted? I told him a pair of shoes, and he gave me a pair to try on, and in bringing me another pair of shoes to try on, the slap of my coat got over the first pair. His mother came out of the parlour, (she knew me for a long time; I have served the gentlewoman with muffins these three years) and said I had taken a pair of shoes. I had the shoes on me stooping to unbuckle my shoe.
GUILTY . (Aged 14.)

Imprisoned twelve months in the House of Correction and
publickly whipped .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

467.
RICHARD DOWELL
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 1st of August , a woman's linen apron, value 2s. the goods of
Mary Allen
, spinster .

GEORGE ALLEN
sworn.
Q. Have you a sister? - Yes.
Q. What is her name? - Mary.
Q. A single woman? - Yes.
Q. Did she lose any property at any time? - Yes.
Q. Do you keep house together? - No. I am a cook.

Q. Had you the care of the linen apron that was stole? - Yes, I had. On the 1st of August I was standing with several other people, to see a horse that had felldown; a witness, Slark, came up to me and told me that I had my pocket picked; I felt and I missed my apron that I had in my pocket before, a linen apron; I brought it from a relation's where my sister had left it; I was going to her; I was bringing it from Maiden-lane, Wood-street to Westminster. Slark told me that was the person, pointing to the prisoner; he had then ran across the way; both of us pursued him, and we took him in Bridge-street.

Q. Did you lose sight of him? - No. A constable was close by, and several people see us stop, and a constable, to see what was the matter, and I gave charge of him to the constable. I found the apron under his great coat.
Q. Who has kept the apron ever since? - The constable.

THOMAS SLARK
sworn.
I am a glass cutter; I see the prisoner, pick Allen's pocket and put it under his coat, and I told Allen of it, and pursued him and took him myself.
Q. Did you see what he had taken? - I had not.
Q. Did you know Mr. Allen at that time? - I did not, he was a stranger to me.
Q. Did you ever lose sight of him? - No.
Q. Did you find the apron on him? - Yes, under his coat.
Q. To whom was it delivered? - To the constable.

JOSHUA GRAY
sworn.

I am a constable; I was coming along Bridge-street, and I see two men got hold of the prisoner at the bar by the collar, and I came up, and they said he had picked a pocket of this apron; so I took him into custody, and took the property at the same time. I see it taken from him.
Prisoner. He did not see it taken from me.

Prosecutor. This is the apron, I know it by the mark
M. A.
2.
Q. Did you know that mark on it before you lost it? - I did.

Prisoner. I left off work about three o'clock on Saturday afternoon, I was going over the water to Kent-street; I am a sawyer by trade; going by Fleet-market, there was a horse fell down in a cart, and this apron fell down from somebody, and I picked it up, and was going on, and these men came and stopped me with it.
The prisoner called two witnesses who gave him a very good character.
GUILTY . (Aged 21.)
For the Navy or Army .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

468.
JOHN YARMOUTH
was indicted for
feloniously stealing, on the 28th of August , a wooden box, value 1s. and fifty six pounds weight of soap, value 2l. the goods of
John Wrigglesworth
.

JOHN WRIGGLESWORTH
sworn.

I am a tallow chandler , Mary-le-bone-lane, Oxford-street; I was out with my horse and cart, carrying some soap about the City, on Friday the 28th of August, and in the Borough; I believe it may be about eight o'clock, I called on an acquaintance, and he asked which way I was going home; and he got up in the cart with me, and he came to Ludgatehill
with me; his name is Hewson, and we stopped together near Ludgate-hill about twenty minutes, and up a man came, and said, is your name - ? I forgot what name; and I said to Mr. Hewson, I don't like that man. With that myfriend got out and went on with his goods; and I went on about five yards, and I felt a sudden jerk in the cart, and I turned round; I was in Ludgate-street, I came over Blackfriars Bridge; I felt the sudden jerk at the bottom of Ludgatehill, going into Fleet-market almost; I turned my head round, and the man had got the box of soap out about three yards from the cart, or not that; I jumped out and catched him with it; the prisoner I did not catch him; I took hold of the box, and he tried to pull it away from him, and then I called out stop thief! and he let it go; with that I put the soap into the cart again, and a gentleman brought him back. He ran up a court in Fleet-street.
Q. How soon was he brought back? - Not more than a minute or two minutes, because there were so many people round.
Q. You are sure it was the prisoner? - Yes. It was as light as day almost with the moon.
Q. How had he the box? - He had it in his arm; and I believe the half hundred of soap get at one end, and I believe it slipped on his toes.
Q. How much soap was there? - It was fifty-six pounds when I weighed it, but it losed by taking about; it was upwards of fifty five pounds when I weighed it again.
Prisoner. Was there a till board to the cart? - No; and as there was none that was the reason that I catched you in it.
Q. Did you see me take it out of the cart? - I did; I turned round immediately on the sudden jerk of the cart.
Court. Did you see him pull it out? - O yes. He did not let it go till I cried stop thief!

JOHN BOLLARD
sworn.
I am constable of St. Bride's parish; I know nothing more than his being brought to the watch-house.

Q. Did you see the prosecutor? - Yes, he charged him with taking half a hundred of soap. The prisoner's behaviour was not altogether decent at the time; he denied it. The box I have had in my possession ever since. The soap was delivered to the prosecutor by the direction of Alderman Clarke.

Prisoner. I would wish to ask him whether the prosecutor did not say he was not sure whether I was the man or no? - I do not remember that. I know he he said before the alderman, that he had hardly occasion to look at him.
Court to Prosecutor. Had you seen him for any length of time at the tail of your cart? - No, only when he tried to struggle with me for the box.

Prisoner. I had come from Machee's, the callico printer, where I work, in Surry; coming through Bridge-street I heard a calling out of stop thief! and I ran with the rest of the people that were running through Bride's passage, and in Harp-alley; I had not got any further than Harp-alley before some people ran beyond me and some behind me, and some people said, where is the man that stole the soap out of the man's cart; I said, I believe he is gone on. Then two men came up and said, they believed I was running; and they took me back to the cart, and asked who was robbed? somebody asked the prosecutor whether he knew the man? he said he did not know whether he knew the man or no; and he said the same before the constable of the night; but he said coming along Bridge-street, a man came behind him, and took the box of soap out of his cart, and he was not sure whether I was the man or not. With that they, no doubt, persuaded him I was the man, which when he came before the magistrate he swore that I was the man that took the soap out of the cart. He told the magistrate, that in Bridge-street three men spoke to him. The justice asked him whether he lost the soap where three menspoke to him? Yes, says he, I lost the box at the very place; says the magistrate, was this man with the men that spoke to you? and he said he was not with the men at the time. I never was in such a place in my life before; I am quite innocent of it, I know no more of it than any thing. I have had people to appear to my character every day in the week, and there was no bill found against me till yesterday morning, and I sent them home.
GUILTY . (Aged 21.)
Transported for seven years .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

469.
MATTHEW SWIFT
was indicted for a fraud .(The indictment opened by Mr. Trebeck, and the case by Mr. Knowlys.)

SARAH BURNETT
sworn.

Q. Do you recollect being any where on the 6th of July last? - I went to Guildhall, for a warrant for
Henry Reeves
and his wife, for beating and abusing me; I met the prisoner at the bar at Guildhall; he tapped me on the shoulder; I was telling a woman that I had with me, that I wanted a warrant, and I never was before a magistrate in my life, and I did not know how to go about it; he said; as I wanted a warrant, he would instruct me how to go about the business. He took me out to the Bell, in Basinghall-street
; he called for pen, ink and paper, and a pint of porter, and said, he would instruct me; he said a shilling warrant was of no use, if I would give him half a crown he would get me a bench warrant, and it would be a shilling serving; he pulled one out of his pocket, as he called it a bench warrant; I asked him if he was authorised to serve a warrant without going before a magistrate? for I was not acquainted with the business; he said, he was, he attended Guildhall, Poultry Compter, the King's Bench, and all other places of confinement; if I would give him three shillings and six-pence, he would do the business. I had but three shillings about me; I had a woman with me, and and I sent her for the money; and then he said he would serve the warrant on Mr. Reeves, at five o'clock in the evening, where I lodged, he had a little business to do first.
Q. Had you told him where Henry Reeves lived? - Yes; he had put it down on his bench warrant as he called it.

Q. Did you, on that day, go before any magistrate? - No, I did not; I see no more that day. I left him then; he said he had a little business to do; and I went to the Bell again, and he was gone and told the landlord how he would serve me for making him fill up a warrant without giving him the money.
Q. Then you gave him no money? - No, I did not.
Mr. Jackson. You and Mrs. Reeves had a quarrel? - Yes.
Q. Any blows past? - Yes.
Q. Who got the better? - I got the better, because I got the warrant; she beat me, but I did not beat her.
Q. You was a good deal agitated after this quarrel; extremely anxious to bring her to justice? - Because I never was used in the manner in my life.
Q. Very anxious to bring her to justice and utterly ignorant how to proceed? -Very ignorant, because I never was before a magistrate in my life.
Q. And meeting with this person, you begged of him to inform you how to proceed in this business? - He said he would.

Q. Perhaps he explained to you, that one sort of warrant would be of no use,because of the bail; but the bail resulting from the other would be in consequence of twenty-four hours notice? - No, he did not say any thing about that.
Q. Notwithstanding this instruction on his part, you gave him no money? - I did not.

Q. You had not had occasion to be before a magistrate before, therefore perhaps you are unacquainted that such assistance is to be found in every police office? - I did not. He said he would manage and make it up.
Q. Perhaps you know that he went to Mr. Reeves in order to make it up? - He did; he had money from him.

HENRY REEVES
sworn.
I live in Bishopsgate-street without, with Mr. Wood and Fossets, cheesemongers.
Q. Do you know Mrs. Barnet? - Yes, she was a lodger of mine.
Q. Had Mrs. Barnet and you any quarrel at any time? - Yes, on Sunday night.
Q. Do you know the prisoner at the bar? - Yes, I know him very well. I was sent for the 6th of July, between three and five; the servant maid came for me from the White Dog.
Q. When you went to the White Dog, who did you see? - I see Mr. Swift standing with his back to a box; I went up to him.
Q. Where is the White Dog public house? - In Widegate-alley.

Q. Did you know on what business you was to meet Mr. Swift at that time? - No, I knew nothing about it. When I came up to him he asked me if my name was Reeves? I said, yes; he said, he had a warrant against me and my wife; I asked him who it came from? he said, from John Barnet and Sarah Barnet.

Q. Is
Sarah Barnet
the woman we have just seen? - Yes. And he said, he should not serve it on me because he had enquired after my character, and I had a very good character, that he only shewed it me; I told him it was of no use, I could not read; he said, he should not serve it on me; I told him it was a thing I was quite unacquainted with; and he said, leave it alone to me, he would put me in a way how to get through it. Then first he said I must give him half a crown for serving it, and sixpence to go the next morning to stop the warrant. I was quite unacquainted with the business; I was never before a court of justice before in my life; I cannot read or write English; I gave him the half crown and sixpence; the half crown for serving it on me, and the sixpence if be would stop the warrant the next morning. He then sat down and wrote me a direction for to meet him at the Helmet, in Bishopsgate-street, and what his name was; he gave me the name of Smith; I have kept it over since.(Read by the clerk of the Court.)
"Mr. Reeves to meet Mr. Smith at the Helmet, to-morrow morning at ten o'clock. Monday, July the 6th, 1795."
The next morning I and my wife and another woman went to meet him; but he was not come. I could not stop, I was obliged to go to work; I went again about eleven o'clock, and then I see him.

Q. What day was this? - The 7th of July, Tuesday, the day after. He was just come in, sitting along side of my wife. I went in and told him that I left my cause entirely to him; and just as I was going out of doors, he asked my wife whether she had any money? and he said, if she would give him half a crown, he would take out a cross warrant. I heard that.
Q. Do you know whether he ever got this cross warrant? - I never asked.
Q. Do you know whether your wife gave him the half crown? - Yes.
Q. Did you see it? - No. I see him, again the 8th of July, the day after, thenhe was in custody, then I gave charge of him, then he was committed.
Court. Was he taken up on your account? - Yes. I met him at Guildhall, and I gave charge of him.
Mr. Jackson. Where do you live? - In Widegate-alley.
Q. You know the prisoner very well? - Yes.
Q. Perhaps you know that he has a wife and a large family? - That I don't know.

Q. I dare say you will be as candid to me as you have been to Mr. Knowlys and other people, with whom you have conversed on this subject. I think when he first met, he said he would undertake to make it up for you? - He did.
Q. You know that this woman, Mrs. Barnet, was extramely enraged against your wife, and meant to prosecute you? - No, I don't know that.
Q. Had you learned from your wife, or any other person that an assault had taken place? - Yes.
Q. Perhaps you knew that Mrs. Barnet meant to take up your wife for an assault? - No, I do not.
Q. But Mrs. Barnet did take out a warrant after that? - She did.
Q. Then when Mr. Swift stated the indignation that Mrs. Barnet was in, he persuaded you to make it up? - No, he did not.
Q. But when you was given to understand, what appears in fact, that warrants were out against you, then at last you thought it time to make it up? - We made it up.
Q. Are you at the expence of the prosecution? - I know nothing at all about the expence. I am bound over to prosecute, that is all I know of expence.
Q. Have you never heard who is to be at the expence of this prosecution? Are you to be at the expence? - It is out of my power.
Q. Then I ask you if any other person, and who? - I cannot tell.
Q. Who applied to you to attend? - I was sent for from the solicitor's office; I had a note.
Q. Do you remember which of the constables told you that all your expences would be paid you? - None of the constables told me that.
Q. Did any person tell you it should? - No.
Q. Do you mean to swear that? - The Solicitor's office told me I believe it was them that we should be paid for our trouble, if she would leave it to them. I never see any constable that I know of.
Q. Did not the assurance go a little further in telling you that you should be well paid? - No.
Q. And that you should be rewarded for the loss of time if you could convict this man, nor you did not say so to Mr. Knowlys? - No, nothing like it.

Q. Then though this person did not come at ten o'clock, he came at eleven, and told you that you might safely leave it to him. Did you; in fact, arrive at any trouble after that? - She had the warrant out the next day.
Q. You see him the next day attending as usual, what appeared to be his vocation? - I did.

Q. I think you have stated that the two shillings and sixpence you gave him was because he would not serve the warrant. Perhaps you know that the most reputable sheriffs office in London takes small fees? - I know nothing about it.
Q. Then though you gave this two shillings and sixpence, was there any liquor or entertainment called for at this public house? - Yes, we had two pints of beer; I paid for them.
Q. Then for this two shillings and sixpence he was once negociating this business with Mrs. Barnet and two days attending you.
Mr. Knowlys. So they made Grizzlegog pay for all? - Yes.
Q. You make a heavy sigh, as many a man does at the lawyer? - Yes.
Q. Do you know any thing about the prosecution and how it is carried on? - No.
Q. You are bound over by the alderman, and the solicitor of the City has carried it on.
Mr. Jackson addressed the jury for the defendant.
GUILTY . (Aged 38.)
Two years in Newgate .
Tried by the London Jury before Mr. RECORDER.

470.
MILES ANDREW SMITH
was indicted for
willful and corrupt perjury .(The indictment opened by Mr. Gurney, and the case by Mr. Knowlys.)

MANOAH SIBLY
sworn.
Q. You are short hand writer to this Court? - Yes.

Q. Have you the original notes of the trial of
James Cooke
the last Session? - I have.
Q. Be so good as to read the evidence that the prisoner at the bar gave on that occasion.
Reads the whole of the evidence.
See the Session paper No. VII. Part II.(The following extracts of which were the assignments of perjury against the prisoner.)
"Q. And so they got safe into the Star and Garter? - Yes.

Q. How were you disposed of there? - I was carried into a room on the left hand side of the passage, and they asked for Sergeant Cooke, and Sergeant
Cooke
came down stairs; I remained a little in that same room, and then I was taken up stairs and locked up in the back garret.
Q. Did you go through the tap room? - I did not.
Q. You never see the tap room at all? - I did not.
Q. You never wrote your name in your life as William Harris? - Yes, I did when I was committed to Guildford gaol, or Bagshot.

Q. Did not you at the police office, at Westminster, write your name as
William Harris
? - No, I did not.(The attestation shewn him.)
Q. Be so good as to look at that, and see whether that is your hand writing? - No, I will swear that is not my hand writing.
Q. Look at it again. There are two William Harrises there, one at the top and the other in the middle of the paper, are neither of them your hand writing? - No.
Q. Is Shepherd there? Look at him? - Yes, that is the man.
Q. You recollect him? - Yes, I think that is the man.
Q. You never see him since you was at the police office, and yet you have senses enough about you to think that is the man? - Yes, I think it is.
Q. And yet you say you did not sign your name there? - All the questions that I heard asked were, what is your name? the sergeant said, William Harris.
Q. Then before you went to the police office, did not you go to Crown-street? -No, not that I know of: I might go through Crown street to it.
Q. You did not stop any where to see any body? - No.

Q. Mr. Dalby, stand up. Tell me whether you did not see that gentleman, and whether you were not examined by him, as to the propriety of being fit for a soldier, before you went to the police office? - No.
Q. Not before you went to slsey Barracks? - Not by any barracks.

Q. Do you know a watchman of the name of
Thomas Bradley
? - No.

Q. Then I ask you this question, whether between the time after you came from the police office some time on Monday night, you did not escape from the room up stairs with your own clothes on, and brought back by Bradley to this house? - No.
Q. Had you ever got out of the Star and Garter before the time you was carried to the police office? - No, never.
Q. Then after you had been at the police office, you swear that you did not get out of this house and brought back by Bradley, a watchman? - No, I did not get out of the house.
Q. (Bradley, stand up.) Look at that person: will you swear that he did not lay hold of you and bring you back to the Star and Garter, you having got away? - Yes, I will.
Q. Do you know a captain Bartholomew? - No.
Q. Is captain Bartholomew here? - Was your person ever examined by him, to see if you was fit to be a soldier? - My person never was examined by any one."

RICHARD HUNT
sworn.
I am in the Loyal Louth Lincolnshire Volunteers.

Q. Was it the same regiment to which Sergeant
Cooke
belonged, that was tried here? - Yes.
Q. Do you know the man at the bar? - Yes, I have seen him.
Q. When did you first see him? -Sometime in April last; he was brought from Chelsea, enlisted by one Brown. I was in the room when he was brought in; I cannot say justly what day it was.
Q. To what house was he brought? - The Star and Garter, Old Palace-yard, that was our rendezvous.
Q. He was in the dining room along with the rest of you? - Yes.
Q. There was a good many more of you there? - Yes.
Q. Whereabouts is the tip room in that house? Is that what you call the tap room? - No, the dining room is up stairs; the tap room is on the right hand side coming in of the street door.
Q. Were you ever in the tap room? - Yes, frequently.

Q. Do you know whether Smith was ever there? - Yes, I know he was there, because I have drank with him in the tap room. He went by the name of William Harris, he signed his name as such however; I did not know any thing of his name but
William Harris
, till after Cooke was taken up. I have seen him once or twice in the tap room or oftner.
Q. How was he kept? - The same as the rest; he went up and down stairs when he pleased; we were never confined only at night when we went to bed.

Q. Were you all permitted to go into the tap room as you pleased? - We were permitted now and then to go down to drink or so with a friend, but we did not run up and down there, because we paid only for the dining room.
Q. Were there any orders against any of you going into this tap room? - No.

Q. Did you see this man attested? - I did not go; he went out of the room with Sergeant
Cooke
, to be attested. I am pretty well assured it was on Monday.
Q. From what you know of him, and see of him, do you know whether he was looked up of a day in the upper room; - He was not.

Q. Do you recollect the circumstance of any watchman bringing in any man? - Yes, I was present when Sergeant Cooke brought
William Harris
up stairs, after he was brought in by the watchman, sergeant Cooke told me so.
Q. He did not deny but what the watchman brought him in, but only excused for it, that he did not mean to desert? -He did not.
Mr. Knapp. Are you at present in this regiment of loyal louth volunteers? - Yes, I have been in the recruiting service; I came now from Watford.
Q. How long have you been from this recruiting house? - I went away the Wednesday after he went away from the house; I come up again on this trial.
Q. How often have you seen Cooke? - Several times.
Q. How often have you conversed on this trial? - He has not conversed with me on this trial; I was sent for last Friday.
Q. Were you told what to say? - I was not.
Q. You know you were not a witness on Cooke's trial? - I was not, because I was sent off to my regiment that I then belonged to, in Dublin barracks.
Q. But not being at the last trial, did not you understand what you were to prove to day? - Yes, to prove that I knew the man when he was at the Star and Garter.
Q. Who told you that? - I have heard different people talk of it, not one in particular.

Q. On your oath did not Mr. Cooke tell you so, that you were to come to prove that you remembered this man at the Star and Garter? - Certainly he did, he told me that I was subpoenaed to be an evidence for him, that I was there at the time, and so I was; I am speaking no more than what is true.
Q. You say that you came here on Friday last, that is a week ago exactly; where have you been living since you have been in town? - I have attended here almost every day.
Q. Has Mr. Cooke been attending with you? - He has not been attending with me, he has been attending in the court.
Q. Have you not been at dinner together? - No, I went home to dinner.
Q. You went home to this recruiting shop? - Yes, I went home, that is where I lodge.

Q. You went home to the rest of your regiment? - Yes, but Cooke was not with me, never particularly, no more than any body else; I have had no conversation with him at all, the other men and me have talked together, but not sergeant Cooke.
Q. You are still in the regiment? - Yes, I am.
Mr. Knowlys. I take it for granted that when you was subpoenaed, it was asked what you could prove, and what you knew of this business? - Yes, certainly.
Q. Another thing, you had no other place to live at but this recruiting house? - No, that is my place, I have no right to be any where else.
Q. And you have talked about this matter among your friends? - Yes, I have
Q. It is not a very common thing for one of your comrades to be indicted for felony? - No, I should be very sorry if it was.

GEORGE BRIDGEFORTH
sworn.

I keep the Star and Garter in Palace-yard, near Abingdon-street; I see the prisoner the latter end of April, when he came to my house, nearly the 27th or 28th, I cannot say particularly, it was Saturday, nearly about the middle of the day.
Q. Who did he come with? - I don't know.
Q. What time did you first see him? - Nearly about two o'clock, in the parlour.

Q. How long did he remain in your house? -
Till Tuesday
morning.
Q. Did he ever go out of your house during that time? - Yes, he went out once to be attested, on Monday.

Q. Did he go out any other time? - Yes, on Monday evening, he was brought in by a watchman, Thomas Bradley; I see him brought in at the door; Bradley asked sergeant Cooke whether that man belonged to him, and he answered that he did, and then they went into the parlour, and I saw no more of them for a little while.
Q. Did you ever see him in the tap room? - I carried tea to him myself in the tap room, he sat behind the door; he was in more than once to the best of my knowledge.

Q. Are you certain you see him twice? - I only speak as to belief that I see him twice, but I am certain once, because I carried tea to him, and two slices of bread and butter, either on Sunday or Monday morning.
Q. Was he at liberty, or was he locked up? - Neither him nor no man was ever locked up in my house, nor would I suffer any such thing.

Q. Then you solemnly swear that he never was locked up in any room in your house? - He was not; I set two rooms to them, one room to sleep in and another to sit in, and I would wish them to be there as much as I can, but they are all over my house. That is the man, I am certain of it.

Q. By what name did he go at your house? - By the name of
William Harris
he answered me, I never heard that his name was Smith till the prosecution of Cooke, and was much surprised to hear it.
Mr. Knapp. You are the landlord of this house, of course every thing is conducted in this house as it ought to be? - It might be so.
Q. There was a good many other recruits in the house? - A good many.
Q. You give them free liberty to run all over the house? They are not confined to one room? - They have four rooms, indeed.
Q. And they had full liberty to go about every part of your house? - Yes, every part except the wine cellar.

Q. You say that as to once that you are sure that you gave him tea in the tap room, but as to any more, being on your oath, you do not choose to swear, either one way or the other? - No more! will not swear to.
Q. How long has your's been a recruiting house? - Since the 17th of March.
Q. A great many recruits in your house at different times? - A great many more than sleep there, at different times.
Q. How many recruits have you had in your house since that time, twenty or thirty? - More than that often in a week.

Q. Sergeant
Cooke
is very lucky? - They come there from other Sergeants.
Mr. Gurney. You have no interest in the recruiting business? - No.
Q. And therefore of course you do not pay attention to the exact number that are in your house?

THOMAS WELLS
sworn.
Q. Do you know the prisoner at the bar? - Yes.

Q. What name do you know him by? -
William Harris
.
Q. Did you ever know him by any other name before the prosecution of Cooke for this robbery? - Never.
Q. When did you first see him? - On the 27th of April, to the best of my knowledge on Saturday.
Q. You are a walter at the Star and Garter? - Yes. When I first see him he was brought in by one Brown from Chelsea, and was taken into the back room.
Q. At what hour? - I cannot say, I am not particular, he came as a recruit; he was taken into a little parlour on the left hand.
Q. In what other parts did you see him? - On Sunday, and on Monday I see him in the tap room.
Q. Are you sure you see him both these days? - Yes.
Q. What was he doing in the tap room? - I really cannot tell, what he was doing. he might be drinking with the rest of the recruits.
Q. Had the recruits in general the liberty of coming into the tap room when they pleased? - Yes, at times, they drink in all parts of the house.
Q. From your observation of that man, did he appear to be much restrained, or more confined than the rest of the recruits? - Not at all.
Q. Did you ever hear him complain when he was in the house, of being robbed or I treated? - Not at all.

Q. Were you present at the time the watchman gave any account of any man? - Yes, and that was the same man; that was on Monday, about twenty minutes after ten in the evening; Bradley brought him in and asked for Mr. Cooke the sergeant, and asked if he did not belong to him, he supposed he was going to desert.
Q. Did Cooke claim him? - Yes, he did.
Q. What did the prisoner say at that time? - I did not hear him make any defence at all.
Q. I believe you did not go to the justice? - I did not.
Mr. Knapp. You say you are a waiter at this rendezvous? - Yes, almost a twelve month.
Q. Are you continued in the employ at present by the last witness? - Yes.
Q. You are sure that he was in the tap room two days? - He was in different times on both days.
Q. You have always said so? - Yes, I said so before to the best of my knowledge.
Q. That was very recent after the transaction took place that you was examined before, when sergeant Cooke was tied? - Yes.
Q. You was more likely to say your recollection of the thing what had happened, then you are now? - I can recollect as well now as then.

Q. So you are sure that you said at the last trial, that he was on Sunday and Monday at different times in the tap room. I will put the question that was put to you the last time, "Did you ever see him in the tap room at all" your answer was,"On Monday he was, in the forenoon, to the best of my knowledge."
"Q. What was he doing there?
"A. He might be drinking or sitting with the rest of the men.
"Q. What part of the house on Sunday?
"A. He was in different parts." On Sunday now you are sure he was in the room, how came you not to say so to the other jury? Stand down.

HENRY MAISTER COOKE
sworn.

Q. You are the brother of
James Cooke
, the man that was tried here? - I am, I am in the life guards.
Q. Did you ever see the prisoner at the bar before? - Yes, at the Star and Garter, in July.
Q. Did you ever see him before July? - No, I did not.
Q. How long was it before the trial of your brother, that you see him? - I cannot say.
Q. By what name did he go by? - I never heard his name mentioned, I only went to see my brother.
Q. What day of the week was it? - I cannot say.
Q. What time of the day, or night? - I cannot tell to an hour, near nine o'clock.
Q. Did you see any watchman at the time you were there? - Yes.
Q. Did he bring any body into the house? - Yes, the prisoner.
Q. What did the watchman says in his hearing, when he brought him in? - He said he brought him in, and asked if he belonged to sergeant Cooke.
Q. Did he say where he found him? - He found him in a back place the back part of the house, but I really cannot say where.
Q. How long did you stay there? - Perhaps three hours.
Mr. Knapp. You don't know even the month, the day of the week, or the hour of the day when this happened; you were a very little time there, only went in to see your brother and come out again.
Court. Are you sure you were there when Bradley brought in the man? - Yes.
Q. (Call Bradley in.) Do you know that man? - Yes, that is the man that brought him in.

THOMAS BRADIEY
sworn.
Q. You are a watchman? - Yes.
Q. Do you know the Star and Garter? - Yes; my box is against the wall of the house.
Q. Did you ever take any man near that house? - I never took any man not till I took one man, and took him up the passage, I brought him down and delivered him to sergeant Cooke.
Q. Where did you find the man? -Up the passage that leads up by my box, by the house; I said to the man, my friend, what do you do up there?

Q.
